value.string_value: {"component_objects":{"details_1":{"type":"grok_share","data":{"profile_user":{"id_str":"44196397","profile_image_url_https":"https://pbs.twimg.com/profile_images/1995407795835772928/Wp7m4L9h.jpg","name":"Elon Musk","screen_name":"elonmusk","highlighted_label":{"description":"X","badge":{"url":"https://pbs.twimg.com/profile_images/1955359038532653056/OSHY3ewP_bigger.jpg"},"url":{"urlType":"DeepLink","url":"https://twitter.com/X"},"userLabelType":"BusinessLabel","userLabelDisplayType":"Badge"},"verified":false,"is_blue_verified":true},"grok_user":{"id_str":"1720665183188922368","profile_image_url_https":"https://pbs.twimg.com/profile_images/1893219113717342208/Vgg2hEPa.jpg","name":"Grok","screen_name":"grok","highlighted_label":{"description":"xAI","badge":{"url":"https://pbs.twimg.com/profile_images/1769430779845611520/lIgjSJGU_bigger.jpg"},"url":{"urlType":"DeepLink","url":"https://twitter.com/xai"},"userLabelType":"BusinessLabel","userLabelDisplayType":"Badge"},"verified":false,"is_blue_verified":true,"verified_type":"Business"},"id":"sEqNa8YLWIizQd8bYqNqbEaUy","conversation_preview":[{"message":"More Sowell multiculturalism quotes","sender":"USER","grokMode":"NORMAL","mediaUrls":[]},{"message":"Here are several notable quotes from Thomas Sowell critiquing multiculturalism and related concepts like diversity (often drawn from his books and columns, such as Intellectuals and Society, Ever Wonder Why?, and syndicated writings): "What 'multiculturalism' boils down to is that you can praise any culture in the world except Western culture—and you cannot blame any culture in the world except Western culture." "The key word among advocates of multiculturalism became 'diversity.' Sweeping claims for the benefits of demographic and cultural diversity in innumerable institutions and circumstances have prevailed without a speck of evidence being asked for or given." (From Intellectuals and Society) On the counterproductive effects: "Among the many irrational ideas about racial and ethnic groups that have polarized societies over the centuries and around the world, few have been more irrational and counterproductive than the current dogmas of multiculturalism." He argues it pronounces all cultures "equally valid" without evidence, discouraging assimilation or improvement, and ultimately harms lagging groups by fostering resentment rather than progress. "Multiculturalism is not just a recognition that different groups have different cultures. items.message:
Here are several notable quotes from Thomas Sowell critiquing **multiculturalism** and related concepts like diversity (often drawn from his books and columns, such as *Intellectuals and Society*, *Ever Wonder Why?*, and syndicated writings):

- "What 'multiculturalism' boils down to is that you can praise any culture in the world except Western cultureâ€”and you cannot blame any culture in the world except Western culture."

- "The key word among advocates of multiculturalism became 'diversity.' Sweeping claims for the benefits of demographic and cultural diversity in innumerable institutions and circumstances have prevailed without a speck of evidence being asked for or given."  
  (From *Intellectuals and Society*)

- On the counterproductive effects: "Among the many irrational ideas about racial and ethnic groups that have polarized societies over the centuries and around the world, few have been more irrational and counterproductive than the current dogmas of multiculturalism."  
  He argues it pronounces all cultures "equally valid" without evidence, discouraging assimilation or improvement, and ultimately harms lagging groups by fostering resentment rather than progress.

- "Multiculturalism is not just a recognition that different groups have different cultures. We all knew that, long before multiculturalism became a cult that has spawned mindless rhapsodies about 'diversity,' without a speck of evidence to substantiate its supposed benefits."

Sowell's broader critique emphasizes that historical successes (like immigrant assimilation in America) came from adopting prevailing cultural norms, not from celebrating unassimilated differences as a virtue. These views appear consistently across his works and interviews.
